CVE-2024-37404
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

6 posts

N/A

1 repos

#search_error

screaminggoat at 2024-10-09T16:28:06.455Z ##

AmberWolf: Ivanti Connect Secure - Authenticated RCE via OpenSSL CRLF Injection (CVE-2024-37404)
Reference: CVE-2024-37404 (9.1 critical, disclosed 08 October 2024 by Ivanti) Improper Input Validation in the admin portal of Ivanti Connect Secure before 22.7R2.1 and 9.1R18.9, or Ivanti Policy Secure before 22.7R1.1 allows a remote authenticated attacker to achieve remote code execution.

Never heard of AmberWolf before this, and they don't mess around: They are the vulnerability reporters and they drop a same-day proof of concept for CVE-2024-37404. In bird culture, that would normally be considered a dick move. In their defense though, look at the timeline: Ivanti sat on the vulnerability for over 90 days, and then admitted that they silently patched it in ICS 22.7R2.1 after AmberWolf threatened to publish vulnerability details back on 16 September 2024. They agreed on a coordinated disclosure date of October's Patch Tuesday (8th).

So Ivanti Connect Secure versions prior to 22.7R2.1 and 22.7R2.2, and Ivanti Policy Secure versions prior to 22.7R1.1, contain a "Carriage Return Line Feed" (CRLF) injection vulnerability which could be exploited by an authenticated administrator to execute arbitrary code with root privileges. It is fixed by updating to ICS version 22.7R2.1, 22.7R2.2, or Ivanti Policy Secure 22.7R1.1. Their proof of concept is a POST request containing a CRLF and OpenSSL payload resulting in a reverse shell running under the root user.

Hilariously, they also confirm Eclypsium's findings that the Ivanti Connect Secure appliance is based on the 11 year old Linux CentOS 6.4.

#ivanti #vulnerability #CVE_2024_37404 #cve #proofofconcept #vulnerabilityanalysis #crlf

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-10-09T16:28:06.000Z ##

AmberWolf: Ivanti Connect Secure - Authenticated RCE via OpenSSL CRLF Injection (CVE-2024-37404)
Reference: CVE-2024-37404 (9.1 critical, disclosed 08 October 2024 by Ivanti) Improper Input Validation in the admin portal of Ivanti Connect Secure before 22.7R2.1 and 9.1R18.9, or Ivanti Policy Secure before 22.7R1.1 allows a remote authenticated attacker to achieve remote code execution.

Never heard of AmberWolf before this, and they don't mess around: They are the vulnerability reporters and they drop a same-day proof of concept for CVE-2024-37404. In bird culture, that would normally be considered a dick move. In their defense though, look at the timeline: Ivanti sat on the vulnerability for over 90 days, and then admitted that they silently patched it in ICS 22.7R2.1 after AmberWolf threatened to publish vulnerability details back on 16 September 2024. They agreed on a coordinated disclosure date of October's Patch Tuesday (8th).

So Ivanti Connect Secure versions prior to 22.7R2.1 and 22.7R2.2, and Ivanti Policy Secure versions prior to 22.7R1.1, contain a "Carriage Return Line Feed" (CRLF) injection vulnerability which could be exploited by an authenticated administrator to execute arbitrary code with root privileges. It is fixed by updating to ICS version 22.7R2.1, 22.7R2.2, or Ivanti Policy Secure 22.7R1.1. Their proof of concept is a POST request containing a CRLF and OpenSSL payload resulting in a reverse shell running under the root user.

Hilariously, they also confirm Eclypsium's findings that the Ivanti Connect Secure appliance is based on the 11 year old Linux CentOS 6.4.

#ivanti #vulnerability #CVE_2024_37404 #cve #proofofconcept #vulnerabilityanalysis #crlf

##
reedmideke@mastodon.social at 2024-10-09T19:20:33.000Z ##

Fun fact, the "Elevated." refers to the privileges of their 2010-era perl CGI scripts

(https://blog.amberwolf.com/blog/2024/october/cve-2024-37404-ivanti-connect-secure-authenticated-rce-via-openssl-crlf-injection/)

#Ivanti

##
screaminggoat at 2024-10-09T18:48:41.970Z ##

@cR0w did you see the AmberWolf blog? https://infosec.exchange/@screaminggoat/113278404949270225

Ivanti sat on the Connect Secure vulnerability CVE-2024-37404 for 90 days, then silently patched it.

decio at 2024-10-04T08:41:39.281Z ##

Recently patched CUPS flaw can be used to amplify DDoS attacks

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/recently-patched-cups-flaw-can-be-used-to-amplify-ddos-attacks/

##
emory@soc.kvet.ch at 2024-10-01T15:23:44.000Z ##

okay here's something useful for #CUPS #RCE: https://cloud.projectdiscovery.io/?template=CVE-2024-47176

> auto-discovering print services and shared printers. cups-browsed binds to INADDR_ANY-631, causing it to trust any packet from any source, and can cause the Get-Printer-Attributes IPP request to an attacker controlled URL. Due to the service binding to *-631 ( INADDR_ANY ), multiple bugs in cups-browsed can be exploited in sequence to introduce a malicious printer to the system.

#infosec #CVE_2024_47176

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-30T13:35:32.084Z ##

Red Hat security advisory: RHBA-2024:7369 - Bug Fix Advisory
See parent toots above for more details about the CUPS vulnerabilities. The rhel9/cups container image has been updated for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9 to address RHSA-2024:7346
Users of rhel9/cups container images are advised to upgrade to these updated images, which contain backported patches to correct these security issues, fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Users of these images are also encouraged to rebuild all container images that depend on these images.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-27T14:57:22.340Z ##

Ubuntu security advisory: USN-7042-1: cups-browsed vulnerability
Simone Margaritelli discovered that cups-browsed could be used to create arbitrary printers from outside the local network. In combination with issues in other printing components, a remote attacker could possibly use this issue to connect to a system, created manipulated PPD files, and execute arbitrary code when a printer is used. This update disables support for the legacy CUPS printer discovery protocol.

The problem can be corrected by updating your system to the following package versions: Ubuntu 24.04

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-27T14:55:12.990Z ##

Sonicwall security advisory: Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities

The SonicWall PSIRT has analyzed CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) to assess their relevance to our products and services.
SonicWall products and cloud services do not incorporate the impacted CUPS software packages and are not affected by these vulnerabilities.

SonicWall PSIRT is aware that a proof of concept (PoC) exploit for this vulnerabilities is publicly available, we have no information regarding any exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

Print Spoolers committing RCEs

https://securityintelligence.com/news/fysa-critical-rce-flaw-in-gnu-linux-systems/

##
threatcodex at 2024-09-27T13:34:01.151Z ##

Attacking UNIX Systems via CUPS, Part I
#CVE_2024_47176 #CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47177
https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/

##
TomSellers at 2024-09-27T13:18:52.066Z ##

FYI for Ubuntu users concerned about the CUPS vulnerability:

Ubuntu released a patch for cups-browsed roughly 16 hours ago. If your system is configured with unattended-upgrades the patch may already be applied. I've seen it automatically applied on two of my lab systems.

As a note, Desktop installations of Ubuntu and Kubuntu appear to be vulnerable in their default state until the patch is applied. Pop!_OS and KDE Neon, both Ubuntu based, are similarly impacted in their default configurations.

Just update your packages and you should be fine.

Reference:
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-7042-1

#security #cups #CVE_2024_47176

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-27T00:12:21.039Z ##

Tenable: CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177: Frequently Asked Questions About Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities
This is perhaps the most informative and comprehensive guide to the CUPS vulnerabilities yet. While I question the use of the phrase zero-days, they were publicly announced prematurely due to a leak ahead of a coordinated disclosure date, and proof of concept has been released. Fortunately, it's not the 9.9 doomsday that everyone was hawk tuahing about. Skibidi I don't think anyone reads what I write anyway. Only in Ohio though.

As @CraigHRowland said:

The bad news is there is a vulnerability in the CUPS printer system on Linux. The good news is nobody has ever gotten their printer working on Linux so they are safe.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-26T21:09:25.449Z ##

SAN ISC: Patch for Critical CUPS vulnerability: Don't Panic

CUPS may use "filters", executables that can be used to convert documents. The part responsible ("cups-filters") accepts unverified data that may then be executed as part of a filter operation. An attacker can use this vulnerability to inject a malicious "printer". The malicious code is triggered once a user uses this printer to print a document. This has little or no impact if CUPS is not listening on port 631, and the system is not used to print documents (like most servers). An attacker may, however, be able to trigger the print operation remotely. On the local network, this is exploitable via DNS service discovery. A proof of concept exploit has been made available.

There is no patch right now. Disable and remove cups-browserd (you probably do not need it anyway). Update CUPS as updates become available. Stop UDP traffic on Port 631.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
decio@infosec.exchange at 2024-10-04T08:41:39.000Z ##

ðŸ‘‡

emory@soc.kvet.ch at 2024-10-01T15:23:44.000Z ##

okay here's something useful for #CUPS #RCE: https://cloud.projectdiscovery.io/?template=CVE-2024-47176

> auto-discovering print services and shared printers. cups-browsed binds to INADDR_ANY-631, causing it to trust any packet from any source, and can cause the Get-Printer-Attributes IPP request to an attacker controlled URL. Due to the service binding to *-631 ( INADDR_ANY ), multiple bugs in cups-browsed can be exploited in sequence to introduce a malicious printer to the system.

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-30T13:35:32.000Z ##

Red Hat security advisory: RHBA-2024:7369 - Bug Fix Advisory
See parent toots above for more details about the CUPS vulnerabilities. The rhel9/cups container image has been updated for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9 to address RHSA-2024:7346
Users of rhel9/cups container images are advised to upgrade to these updated images, which contain backported patches to correct these security issues, fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Users of these images are also encouraged to rebuild all container images that depend on these images.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T14:57:22.000Z ##

Ubuntu security advisory: USN-7042-1: cups-browsed vulnerability
Simone Margaritelli discovered that cups-browsed could be used to create arbitrary printers from outside the local network. In combination with issues in other printing components, a remote attacker could possibly use this issue to connect to a system, created manipulated PPD files, and execute arbitrary code when a printer is used. This update disables support for the legacy CUPS printer discovery protocol.

The problem can be corrected by updating your system to the following package versions: Ubuntu 24.04

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T14:55:12.000Z ##

Sonicwall security advisory: Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities

The SonicWall PSIRT has analyzed CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) to assess their relevance to our products and services.
SonicWall products and cloud services do not incorporate the impacted CUPS software packages and are not affected by these vulnerabilities.

SonicWall PSIRT is aware that a proof of concept (PoC) exploit for this vulnerabilities is publicly available, we have no information regarding any exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

FYI for Ubuntu users concerned about the CUPS vulnerability:

Ubuntu released a patch for cups-browsed roughly 16 hours ago. If your system is configured with unattended-upgrades the patch may already be applied. I've seen it automatically applied on two of my lab systems.

As a note, Desktop installations of Ubuntu and Kubuntu appear to be vulnerable in their default state until the patch is applied. Pop!_OS and KDE Neon, both Ubuntu based, are similarly impacted in their default configurations.

Just update your packages and you should be fine.

Reference:
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-7042-1

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:09:25.000Z ##

SAN ISC: Patch for Critical CUPS vulnerability: Don't Panic

CUPS may use "filters", executables that can be used to convert documents. The part responsible ("cups-filters") accepts unverified data that may then be executed as part of a filter operation. An attacker can use this vulnerability to inject a malicious "printer". The malicious code is triggered once a user uses this printer to print a document. This has little or no impact if CUPS is not listening on port 631, and the system is not used to print documents (like most servers). An attacker may, however, be able to trigger the print operation remotely. On the local network, this is exploitable via DNS service discovery. A proof of concept exploit has been made available.

There is no patch right now. Disable and remove cups-browserd (you probably do not need it anyway). Update CUPS as updates become available. Stop UDP traffic on Port 631.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:06:29.000Z ##

Palo Alto Networks advisory: CVE-2024-47076 Informational: No Impact of CUPS Vulnerabilities on Palo Alto Networks Products
The Palo Alto Networks Product Security Assurance team has evaluated CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) as they relate to our products. Based on current information, Palo Alto Networks products and cloud services do not contain affected CUPS-related software packages and are not impacted by these issues.

Note: PAN on top of the social media scene or have people giving them a heads up.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #PaloAltoNetworks #vulnerability #cve

CUPS may use "filters", executables that can be used to convert documents. The part responsible ("cups-filters") accepts unverified data that may then be executed as part of a filter operation. An attacker can use this vulnerability to inject a malicious "printer". The malicious code is triggered once a user uses this printer to print a document. An attacker may, however, be able to trigger the print operation remotely. On the local network, this is exploitable via DNS service discovery. A proof of concept exploit has been made available.

There is no patch right now. Disable and remove cups-browserd (you probably do not need it anyway). Update CUPS as updates become available. Stop UDP traffic on Port 631.

The SonicWall PSIRT has analyzed CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) to assess their relevance to our products and services.

SonicWall PSIRT is aware that a proof of concept (PoC) exploit for this vulnerabilities is publicly available, we have no information regarding any exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
TomSellers@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T13:18:52.000Z ##

FYI for Ubuntu users concerned about the CUPS vulnerability:

Ubuntu released a patch for cups-browsed roughly 16 hours ago. If your system is configured with unattended-upgrades the patch may already be applied. I've seen it automatically applied on two of my lab systems.

As a note, Desktop installations of Ubuntu and Kubuntu appear to be vulnerable in their default state until the patch is applied. Pop!_OS and KDE Neon, both Ubuntu based, are similarly impacted in their default configurations.

Just update your packages and you should be fine.

Reference:
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-7042-1

#security #cups #CVE_2024_47176

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T00:12:21.000Z ##

Tenable: CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177: Frequently Asked Questions About Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities
This is perhaps the most informative and comprehensive guide to the CUPS vulnerabilities yet. While I question the use of the phrase zero-days, they were publicly announced prematurely due to a leak ahead of a coordinated disclosure date, and proof of concept has been released. Fortunately, it's not the 9.9 doomsday that everyone was hawk tuahing about. Skibidi I don't think anyone reads what I write anyway. Only in Ohio though.

As @CraigHRowland said:

The bad news is there is a vulnerability in the CUPS printer system on Linux. The good news is nobody has ever gotten their printer working on Linux so they are safe.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:09:25.000Z ##

SAN ISC: Patch for Critical CUPS vulnerability: Don't Panic

CUPS may use "filters", executables that can be used to convert documents. The part responsible ("cups-filters") accepts unverified data that may then be executed as part of a filter operation. An attacker can use this vulnerability to inject a malicious "printer". The malicious code is triggered once a user uses this printer to print a document. This has little or no impact if CUPS is not listening on port 631, and the system is not used to print documents (like most servers). An attacker may, however, be able to trigger the print operation remotely. On the local network, this is exploitable via DNS service discovery. A proof of concept exploit has been made available.

There is no patch right now. Disable and remove cups-browserd (you probably do not need it anyway). Update CUPS as updates become available. Stop UDP traffic on Port 631.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:06:29.000Z ##

Palo Alto Networks advisory: CVE-2024-47076 Informational: No Impact of CUPS Vulnerabilities on Palo Alto Networks Products
The Palo Alto Networks Product Security Assurance team has evaluated CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) as they relate to our products. Based on current information, Palo Alto Networks products and cloud services do not contain affected CUPS-related software packages and are not impacted by these issues.

Note: PAN on top of the social media scene or have people giving them a heads up.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #PaloAltoNetworks #vulnerability #cve

##
lkarlslund at 2024-09-30T08:09:30.158Z ##

Use my new tool 'jugular' to do ultrafast scans of your internal networks (or the entire Internet?) for open (likely vulnerable) CUPS-browsed instances.

Many will be affected by the multiple CUPS vulnerabilities we learned about last week (CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177) and this should help you map out what you have in your infrastructure.

It's for Linux only, as it's written for performance (direct UDP packet creation and sending). There's a compiled x64 Linux binary available, otherwise you can build it yourself.

The debacle about the entire CUPS thing is a mess. Of course getting root by installing a malicious printer is bad, but it does require the target to actually print something. I think the potential for weaponizing the parsing problems is worse though.

Let me know what you think, comments and input is welcome.

https://github.com/lkarlslund/jugular

##
patchnow24x7 at 2024-09-28T07:45:51.763Z ##

ATTENTION LINUX USERS!!

Multiple Critical vulnerabilities in CUPS (Common Unix Printing System) chained for Remote Code Execution.
POC is available publicly!

Advisories:
https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/security/advisories/GHSA-rj88-6mr5-rcw8

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libcupsfilters/security/advisories/GHSA-w63j-6g73-wmg5

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libppd/security/advisories/GHSA-7xfx-47qg-grp6

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-filters/security/advisories/GHSA-p9rh-jxmq-gq47

POC:
https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/security/advisories/GHSA-rj88-6mr5-rcw8

https://github.com/RickdeJager/cupshax/tree/main

Fixes:
CVE-2024-47175 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libppd/commit/d681747ebf

CVE-2024-47076 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libcupsfilters/commit/95576ec3

CVE-2024-47176 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/commit/1debe6b140c(temporary workaround)

Vendor Advisories:

RedHat: https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/red-hat-response-openprinting-cups-vulnerabilities

PaloAlto: https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2024-47076

Canonical: https://ubuntu.com/blog/cups-remote-code-execution-vulnerability-fix-available

##
screaminggoat at 2024-10-09T21:09:56.779Z ##

GitLab security advisory: GitLab Critical Patch Release: 17.4.2, 17.3.5, 17.2.9

  • CVE-2024-9164 (9.6 critical) Run pipelines on arbitrary branches
  • CVE-2024-8970 (8.2 high) An attacker can impersonate arbitrary user
  • CVE-2024-8977 (8.2 high) SSRF in Analytics Dashboard
  • CVE-2024-9631 (7.5 high) Viewing diffs of MR with conflicts can be slow
  • CVE-2024-6530 (7.3 high) HTMLi in OAuth page
  • CVE-2024-9623 (4.9 medium) Deploy Keys can push changes to an archived repository
  • CVE-2024-5005 (4.3 medium) Guests can disclose project templates
  • CVE-2024-9596 (3.7 low) GitLab instance version disclosed to unauthorized users

No mention of exploitation

#gitlab #patchtuesday #cve #vulnerability

GitLab security advisory: GitLab Critical Patch Release: 17.4.2, 17.3.5, 17.2.9

  • CVE-2024-9164 (9.6 critical) Run pipelines on arbitrary branches
  • CVE-2024-8970 (8.2 high) An attacker can impersonate arbitrary user
  • CVE-2024-8977 (8.2 high) SSRF in Analytics Dashboard
  • CVE-2024-9631 (7.5 high) Viewing diffs of MR with conflicts can be slow
  • CVE-2024-6530 (7.3 high) HTMLi in OAuth page
  • CVE-2024-9623 (4.9 medium) Deploy Keys can push changes to an archived repository
  • CVE-2024-5005 (4.3 medium) Guests can disclose project templates
  • CVE-2024-9596 (3.7 low) GitLab instance version disclosed to unauthorized users

No mention of exploitation

#gitlab #patchtuesday #cve #vulnerability

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-10-09T21:09:56.000Z ##

Today in #fedora infra land:
* Built a ton of koji builds for the new exciting CVE-2024-9427. (all fedora + epel + a 1.34.x for our hubs now + 1.35.x for our hubs when we upgrade tomorrow.
* Meetings
* Re-installed a a bunch of openqa vmhosts and db server and workers with @adamw 3 less rhel8 installs and standardized openqa workers!
* tomorrow koji outage and some cert reissues and a bunch more meetings.

screaminggoat at 2024-10-07T17:13:38.153Z ##

Apple security advisory: About the security content of Apple TV 1.5.0.152 for Windows
Apple belatedly publishes the advisory for Apple TV which was supposed to be released Thursday. CVE-2024-44157 is a stack buffer overflow that could allow for unexpected system termination if Video Playback parses a malicious crafted video file. No mention of exploitation. h/t: @applsec

#apple #cve #vulnerability

screaminggoat at 2024-10-02T16:30:05.160Z ##

Google Chrome security advisory: Stable Channel Update for Desktop
New version 129.0.6668.89/.90 for Windows, Mac and 129.0.6668.89 for Linux includes 4 security fixes, 3 externally reported:

  • CVE-2024-7025 (high) Integer overflow in Layout
  • CVE-2024-9369 (high) Insufficient data validation in Mojo
  • CVE-2024-9370 (high) Inappropriate implementation in V8

No mention of exploitation.

#google #chrome #vulnerability #cve

##

CVE-2024-47175
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.04%

13 posts

N/A

1 repos

https://github.com/lkarlslund/jugular

lkarlslund at 2024-09-30T08:09:30.158Z ##

Use my new tool 'jugular' to do ultrafast scans of your internal networks (or the entire Internet?) for open (likely vulnerable) CUPS-browsed instances.

Many will be affected by the multiple CUPS vulnerabilities we learned about last week (CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177) and this should help you map out what you have in your infrastructure.

It's for Linux only, as it's written for performance (direct UDP packet creation and sending). There's a compiled x64 Linux binary available, otherwise you can build it yourself.

The debacle about the entire CUPS thing is a mess. Of course getting root by installing a malicious printer is bad, but it does require the target to actually print something. I think the potential for weaponizing the parsing problems is worse though.

Let me know what you think, comments and input is welcome.

https://github.com/lkarlslund/jugular

##
patchnow24x7 at 2024-09-28T07:45:51.763Z ##

ATTENTION LINUX USERS!!

Multiple Critical vulnerabilities in CUPS (Common Unix Printing System) chained for Remote Code Execution.
POC is available publicly!

Advisories:
https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/security/advisories/GHSA-rj88-6mr5-rcw8

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libcupsfilters/security/advisories/GHSA-w63j-6g73-wmg5

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libppd/security/advisories/GHSA-7xfx-47qg-grp6

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-filters/security/advisories/GHSA-p9rh-jxmq-gq47

POC:
https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/

https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/security/advisories/GHSA-rj88-6mr5-rcw8

https://github.com/RickdeJager/cupshax/tree/main

Fixes:
CVE-2024-47175 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libppd/commit/d681747ebf

CVE-2024-47076 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/libcupsfilters/commit/95576ec3

CVE-2024-47176 : https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups-browsed/commit/1debe6b140c(temporary workaround)

Vendor Advisories:

RedHat: https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/red-hat-response-openprinting-cups-vulnerabilities

PaloAlto: https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2024-47076

Canonical: https://ubuntu.com/blog/cups-remote-code-execution-vulnerability-fix-available

#PatchNOW
#Vulnerability
#ComputerSecurity
#hacked
#Cyberattack
#infosec
#informationsecurity
#DataBreach
#cybersecurity

freexian@hachyderm.io at 2024-09-27T15:28:45.000Z ##

As concluded by the Debian Security Team â€“and we concurâ€“ the first updates to address the vulnerabilities will be done in unstable to evaluate if any regression is likely. Once we are confident with the fixes, we will upload to the other releases.

The four related CVEs can be tracked with the following links:

https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47076
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47175
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47176
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47177

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T14:55:12.000Z ##

Sonicwall security advisory: Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities

The SonicWall PSIRT has analyzed CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) to assess their relevance to our products and services.
SonicWall products and cloud services do not incorporate the impacted CUPS software packages and are not affected by these vulnerabilities.

SonicWall PSIRT is aware that a proof of concept (PoC) exploit for this vulnerabilities is publicly available, we have no information regarding any exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
adulau@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T04:17:33.000Z ##

All versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) are affected by CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176 and CVE-2024-47177, but are not vulnerable in their default configurations.
https://vulnerability.circl.lu/bundle/3eaf0fde-67ad-4326-a84a-2e4ff201a8e9

##
ache@mastodon.xyz at 2024-09-27T02:06:32.000Z ##

@bohwaz Je vois rien en dessous de 8,4 perso ...

Ok, c'est pas un 9,9, mais 4 > 8.

https://www.tenable.com/blog/cve-2024-47076-cve-2024-47175-cve-2024-47176-cve-2024-47177-faq-cups-vulnerabilities

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T00:12:21.000Z ##

Tenable: CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177: Frequently Asked Questions About Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities
This is perhaps the most informative and comprehensive guide to the CUPS vulnerabilities yet. While I question the use of the phrase zero-days, they were publicly announced prematurely due to a leak ahead of a coordinated disclosure date, and proof of concept has been released. Fortunately, it's not the 9.9 doomsday that everyone was hawk tuahing about. Skibidi I don't think anyone reads what I write anyway. Only in Ohio though.

As @CraigHRowland said:

The bad news is there is a vulnerability in the CUPS printer system on Linux. The good news is nobody has ever gotten their printer working on Linux so they are safe.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
jwildeboer@social.wildeboer.net at 2024-09-26T22:10:22.000Z ##

@GossiTheDog @dangoodin The currently assigned CVE's have these CVSS scores (which are NOT the 9.9 score claimed by the person who found the vulnerability):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47177 Score: 6.1
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47176 Score 7.5
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47175 Score 7.7
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47076 Score 8.2

Overall rating at Red Hat is "important". Immediate workaround is available. Fixes are coming.

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:06:29.000Z ##

Palo Alto Networks advisory: CVE-2024-47076 Informational: No Impact of CUPS Vulnerabilities on Palo Alto Networks Products
The Palo Alto Networks Product Security Assurance team has evaluated CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) as they relate to our products. Based on current information, Palo Alto Networks products and cloud services do not contain affected CUPS-related software packages and are not impacted by these issues.

Note: PAN on top of the social media scene or have people giving them a heads up.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #PaloAltoNetworks #vulnerability #cve

CVE-2024-47177
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.04%

2 repos

https://github.com/lkarlslund/jugular

https://github.com/referefref/cupspot-2024-47177

lkarlslund at 2024-09-30T08:09:30.158Z ##

Use my new tool 'jugular' to do ultrafast scans of your internal networks (or the entire Internet?) for open (likely vulnerable) CUPS-browsed instances.

Many will be affected by the multiple CUPS vulnerabilities we learned about last week (CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177) and this should help you map out what you have in your infrastructure.

It's for Linux only, as it's written for performance (direct UDP packet creation and sending). There's a compiled x64 Linux binary available, otherwise you can build it yourself.

The debacle about the entire CUPS thing is a mess. Of course getting root by installing a malicious printer is bad, but it does require the target to actually print something. I think the potential for weaponizing the parsing problems is worse though.

Let me know what you think, comments and input is welcome.

https://github.com/lkarlslund/jugular

##
anthonyfloyd@mastodon.social at 2024-09-27T15:58:07.000Z ##

Holy crap. Linux admins, disable your cupsd print services and/or block udp/631 ASAP , re: CVE-2024-47176 and CVE-2024-47177.

Here's the background (an interesting and somewhat terrifying read):

https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/index.html

##
anthonyfloyd@mastodon.social at 2024-09-27T15:58:07.000Z ##

Holy crap. Linux admins, disable your cupsd print services and/or block udp/631 ASAP , re: CVE-2024-47176 and CVE-2024-47177.

Here's the background (an interesting and somewhat terrifying read):

https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/index.html

##
freexian@hachyderm.io at 2024-09-27T15:28:45.000Z ##

As concluded by the Debian Security Team â€“and we concurâ€“ the first updates to address the vulnerabilities will be done in unstable to evaluate if any regression is likely. Once we are confident with the fixes, we will upload to the other releases.

The four related CVEs can be tracked with the following links:

https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47076
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47175
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47176
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2024-47177

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T14:55:12.000Z ##

Sonicwall security advisory: Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities

The SonicWall PSIRT has analyzed CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) to assess their relevance to our products and services.
SonicWall products and cloud services do not incorporate the impacted CUPS software packages and are not affected by these vulnerabilities.

SonicWall PSIRT is aware that a proof of concept (PoC) exploit for this vulnerabilities is publicly available, we have no information regarding any exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve #proofofconcept

##
adulau@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T04:17:33.000Z ##

All versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) are affected by CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176 and CVE-2024-47177, but are not vulnerable in their default configurations.
https://vulnerability.circl.lu/bundle/3eaf0fde-67ad-4326-a84a-2e4ff201a8e9

ache@mastodon.xyz at 2024-09-27T02:06:32.000Z ##

@bohwaz Je vois rien en dessous de 8,4 perso ...

Ok, c'est pas un 9,9, mais 4 > 8.

https://www.tenable.com/blog/cve-2024-47076-cve-2024-47175-cve-2024-47176-cve-2024-47177-faq-cups-vulnerabilities

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-27T00:12:21.000Z ##

Tenable: CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47175, CVE-2024-47176, CVE-2024-47177: Frequently Asked Questions About Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) Vulnerabilities
This is perhaps the most informative and comprehensive guide to the CUPS vulnerabilities yet. While I question the use of the phrase zero-days, they were publicly announced prematurely due to a leak ahead of a coordinated disclosure date, and proof of concept has been released. Fortunately, it's not the 9.9 doomsday that everyone was hawk tuahing about. Skibidi I don't think anyone reads what I write anyway. Only in Ohio though.

As @CraigHRowland said:

The bad news is there is a vulnerability in the CUPS printer system on Linux. The good news is nobody has ever gotten their printer working on Linux so they are safe.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #vulnerability #cve

##
jwildeboer@social.wildeboer.net at 2024-09-26T22:40:16.000Z ##

@jschauma We set UI:N as once the malicious printer shows up, it could also be fed a print job by an automated queue, AFAICS. But I will ask internally about that. UPDATE for CVE-2024-47177 we did set UI:R but that one got a total of 6.2 Full string is CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:L see https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47177

##
jwildeboer@social.wildeboer.net at 2024-09-26T22:10:22.000Z ##

@GossiTheDog @dangoodin The currently assigned CVE's have these CVSS scores (which are NOT the 9.9 score claimed by the person who found the vulnerability):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47177 Score: 6.1
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47176 Score 7.5
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47175 Score 7.7
https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2024-47076 Score 8.2

Overall rating at Red Hat is "important". Immediate workaround is available. Fixes are coming.

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-26T21:06:29.000Z ##

Palo Alto Networks advisory: CVE-2024-47076 Informational: No Impact of CUPS Vulnerabilities on Palo Alto Networks Products
The Palo Alto Networks Product Security Assurance team has evaluated CVE-2024-47076, CVE-2024-47177, CVE-2024-47175, and CVE-2024-47176 in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) as they relate to our products. Based on current information, Palo Alto Networks products and cloud services do not contain affected CUPS-related software packages and are not impacted by these issues.

Note: PAN on top of the social media scene or have people giving them a heads up.

#CVE_2024_47076 #CVE_2024_47177 #CVE_2024_47175 #CVE_2024_47176 #CUPS #linux #PaloAltoNetworks #vulnerability #cve
